questions.text: Mr. Sonu is brought to the hospital because his family members feel that his movements and activities have become very slow.  On examination, the patient has tremors, slurred speech, rigidity, and impaired cerebellar function. He also has orthostatic hypotension. The MRI of his brain is shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical presentation and the MRI showing hot cross bun sign suggest that the most likely diagnosis is multiple system atrophy. 

Multiple system atrophy (MSA) is a type of atypical Parkinson's disease. Along with the features of Parkinson's disease, they also have cerebellar and autonomic features. The common autonomic feature seen in these patients is orthostatic hypotension. MSA is characterized by the presence of degeneration in the striatum, cerebellum, and inferior olivary nuclei coupled with characteristic glial cytoplasmic inclusions. These inclusions stain positively for α-synuclein.

Other options:

Option A- Pantothenate kinase-associated neurodegeneration (PKAN) formerly known as Hallervorden-Spatz disease is caused by a mutation in the PANK2 gene. It usually occurs in childhood and has features of dystonia, parkinsonism, and spasticity. MRI shows the low signal abnormality in the center of the globus pallidus due to iron accumulation. This is known as the eye of the tiger sign.

The below image shows the Eye of the tiger sign seen in PKAN:

 

Option B- Parkinson's disease (PD) usually presents with bradykinesia, rigidity, and tremors. MRI is not useful in the diagnosis of the disease. Imaging of the brain dopamine system in patients with PD can be performed using positron emission tomography (PET) or single-photon emission computed tomography (SPECT). They show reduced and asymmetric uptake of striatal dopaminergic biomarkers, particularly in the posterior putamen.

Option D- Progressive supranuclear palsy (PSP) is a form of atypical parkinsonism that is characterized by slow ocular saccades, eyelid apraxia, and restricted vertical eye movements with downward gaze palsy. Patients also have hyperextension of the neck with gait disturbances and frequent falls. MRI may reveal characteristic atrophy of the midbrain with normal pons. This is called a hummingbird sign. There is degeneration of the striatum, subthalamic nucleus, midline thalamic nuclei, and pallidum, coupled with neurofibrillary tangles and inclusions that stain for tau protein.

The below image shows the hummingbird sign seen in PSP:

questions.text:
A soldier is brought to the hospital after receiving a blow on the head during a war. There is no history of loss of consciousness. He opens his eyes spontaneously, obeys commands, and is able to converse normally, being oriented to time, place and person. Using the GCS scoring, the head injury of this patient is classified as:

GCS - Glasgow Coma Scale
questions.solution:
The head injury of this patient is classified as minor, using the Glasgow Coma Scale score. GCS score of 15 in a patient with no loss of consciousness is called a minor head injury.

Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS) is used in the assessment of patients with a head injury. The GCS score based on the given clinical scenario is 15 (E4 V5 M6).

It is calculated as follows

  • Eye-opening: Spontaneous, Score = 4
  • Verbal response: Normal oriented conversation, score = 5
  • Motor response: Obeys commands, score = 6

Based on the GCS score, the head injury sustained can be classified as follows:

GCS Score

 

  • 15 with no loss of consciousness represents minor head injury
  • 13-15 represent mild injury
  • 9-12 represent moderate injury
  • scores ≤8 represent severe injury 

Related Pearl: Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS)

GCS Score

  • 13-15 represent mild injury
  • 9-12 represent moderate injury
  • Scores ≤8 represent severe injury 

Head Injury Severity: Clinical classification 

Eyes Opening

 Score
Spontaneously 4
To verbal command 3
To painful stimulus 2
Do not open 1

Non-testable

 NT

 

Verbal response Score
Normal-oriented conversation 5
Confused 4
Inappropriate words only 3
Sounds only 2
No sounds 1

Non-testable

 NT

 

Motor Response Score
Obeys commands 6
Localizes to pain 5
Withdrawal response to pain 4
Abnormal flexion/ Decorticate posturing  3
Abnormal extension/ Decerebrate posturing  2
No motor response 1

Non-testable

 NT

Minimum value: 3

Maximum value: 15

  • GCS, in particular, the motor score, is the best predictor of neurological outcome.
  • If an area cannot be assessed, no numerical score is given for that region, and it is considered “non-testable." (NT)
  • In case of endotracheal intubation or tracheostomy, the verbal component of the score is denoted as NT.
  • A score of  ‘1’ is not recorded in missing components, instead, NT is used
  • when a component is Not Testable, a total score is not recorded because the score will be low and this could be confusing to medical colleagues. This may also imply that the patient is more unwell than they actually are.

 

NOTE: 

A new parameter, "pupil reactivity score" has been added to GCS, and now, it is referred to as GCS-P.

P stands for "Pupils unreactive to light"

Pupils unreactive to light Score
Both pupils 2
One pupil 1 
Neither  0

The pupillary score is subtracted from the GCS score to give the final value. Therefore, the range of GCS-P is 1–15.

Note: The minimum frequency of observations for patients with GCS equal to 15 should be as follows, starting after the initial assessment in the emergency department:

  • Half-hourly for 2 hours,
  • Then 1-hourly for 4 hours,
  • 2-hourly thereafter.

Should the patient with GCS equal to 15 deteriorate at any time after the initial 2-hour period, observations should revert to half-hourly and follow the original frequency schedule.

questions.text: A patient is admitted to the hospital for management of burns. He is being treated for severe pain with fentanyl being administered in a manner as seen in the image below. The false statement regarding this drug delivery system is:

choices.text: Delivers the drug into systemic circulation via the stratum basale
Steady plasma concentration of the drug without fluctuations
Absorption of the drug occurs more readily through burned skin
A priming dose of the drug already exists on a micropore membrane

questions.solution:
The image shows a transdermal patch. The false statement regarding this drug delivery system is that it delivers the drug into systemic circulation via stratum basale. It delivers the drug into the systemic circulation via the stratum corneum.

The below diagram shows the components of a transdermal patch:

 

The drug exists in a reservoir between a backing film and a rate-controlling micropore membrane. The micropore membrane is such that the rate of drug delivery to the skin is less than the slowest possible rate of absorption from the skin.

A priming dose of the drug is present on the undersurface of the membrane, impregnated in an adhesive. Once the patch is applied, the drug is delivered to the skin surface by diffusion, followed by its percutaneous absorption into circulation. Areas such as the chest, abdomen, upper arm, lower back, buttock, or mastoid region are utilized for the application of the patch.

The drug is delivered at a constant rate irrespective of the site of application. They provide steady plasma concentrations of the drug without fluctuations.

Systemic absorption of the drug occurs more readily through the skin that is abraded, burned, or denuded. Absorption through the skin can be increased by suspending the drug in an oily vehicle and rubbing this preparation into the skin.

Transdermal patches like these are available for 

  • Nicotine for smoking cessation
  • Oestradiol for HRT
  • GTN for angina
  • Fentanyl for analgesia

Patient compliance is better compared to oral tablets of the same drug. Side effects may include local irritation and mild erythema.

questions.text: A 65-year-old man presents with complaints of hematuria, fever, and weight loss. On examination, there is a palpable mass in the left iliac fossa. Histopathological features of the mass are shown in the image below. Identify the false statement about this type of renal cell carcinoma.

choices.text: Most common type of renal cell carcinoma
Is associated with von Hippel-Lindau syndrome
Commonly arise from distal convoluted tubules
May extend into the inferior vena cava

questions.solution:
The false statement about this type of renal cell carcinoma is that it arises from the distal convoluted tubules.

The given clinical vignette of a man in his 6th decade of life presenting with symptoms of hematuria, fever, and weight loss and examination showing a palpable mass in the left iliac fossa with the histopathological image given above is indicative of clear cell carcinoma.

Clear cell carcinoma is the most common type of renal cell cancer and the third most common of urological cancers.

Most of the cases are sporadic, but can also occur either in familial forms or in association with von Hippel-Lindau (VHL) disease. Nevertheless, all three forms are associated with the loss of sequence of the short arm of chromosome 3.

Those with VHL disease inherit a germline mutation of the VHL gene on chromosomal band 3p25 and lose the second allele by somatic mutation. This VHL gene is involved in the majority of sporadic clear cell carcinomas. Cytogenetic abnormalities giving rise to loss of a segment on chromosome 3p that has the VHL gene are seen in sporadic renal cell cancers. The second, non-deleted allele is inactivated by a somatic mutation or hypermethylation. Thus, loss or inactivation of both copies of the VHL gene is the common underlying molecular abnormality in both sporadic and familial forms of clear cell carcinomas.

The VHL protein causes the degradation of hypoxia-induced factors (HIFs), which are transcription factors that contribute to carcinogenesis by stimulating the expression of vascular endothelial growth factor (VEGF) that helps drive tumour cell growth.

Histologically, they are composed of cells with clear cytoplasm. Most of them arise from the proximal tubular epithelium and usually occur as solitary unilateral lesions. They are bright yellow-grey-white spherical masses of variable size that distort the renal outline.

The margins are sharply defined and confined within the renal capsule. In clear cell carcinoma, the growth pattern varies from solid to trabecular (cordlike) or tubular (resembling tubules). The tumour cells have a rounded or polygonal shape and abundant clear or granular cytoplasm, which contains glycogen and lipids.

One of the characteristic features of clear cell carcinoma is its tendency to grow as a solid column of cells that extend from the renal vein, up to the inferior vena cava, and sometimes as far as the right side of the heart.

questions.text: A young man suffered a trauma to his right hand while playing basketball. 3 weeks later, he reports to the orthopedician because of pain and stiffness over the right wrist. On examination, wrist movements are limited and painful. He is diagnosed with Kienböck's disease. This condition involves avascular necrosis of:
questions.solution:
Kienböck's disease involves avascular necrosis of the lunate.

This condition is usually seen in young adults, who present with pain and stiffness in the wrist. A history of trauma may be present. On examination, localized tenderness can be appreciated over the lunate, and a reduction in grip strength can be noted. Limited and painful wrist movements are noted in the later stages of the disease.

It involves four stages: 

  • Stage 1 involves ischemia of the bone, without any clinical or radiographic abnormality 
  • Stage 2 shows trabecular necrosis with reactive new bone formation. There is increased radiographic density, but little/no distortion of the shape
  • Stage 3 involves the collapse of the bone
  • Stage 4 is characterized by disruption of radiocarpal congruence and secondary osteoarthritis

In the initial stages, an X-ray might be normal, therefore an MRI with gadolinium enhancement is the investigation of choice. 

Management includes the use of splints and vascularized bone grafts for the early stages of the disease and total wrist fusion/replacement for advanced disease.

Note: Avascular necrosis of the scaphoid occurs due to a fracture of the waist of the scaphoid bone.

questions.text:
Match the enzyme with the disease caused by its deficiency:
           Enzyme          Disease
 1. Glucose-6-phosphatase a. Hers disease
 2. Liver phosphorylase b. Farber disease
 3. Fumarylacetoacetate                 hydrolase c. von Gierke disease
 4. Ceramidase d. Tyrosinemia type I
questions.solution:
The correct sequence is 1-c, 2-a, 3-d, 4-b as shown in the table below.

Enzyme Disease
Glucose-6-phosphate von Gierke disease
Liver phosphorylase  Hers disease
Fumarylacetoacetate hydrolase Tyrosinemia type I

von Gierke disease is caused to glucose-6-phosphate deficiency and patients with this condition have hypoglycemia, lactic academia, ketosis, hyperlipidemia and liver and renal tubule cells having glycogen deposits.

Hers disease is caused due to liver phosphorylase deficiency and in this condition, glycogen accumulates in liver leading to hepatomegaly, and there is hypoglycemia

Tyrosinemia type I is caused due to a deficiency of the enzyme fumarylacetoacetate hydrolase. The untreated type usually presents in young infants with severe liver involvement or later with liver and renal tubular dysfunction associated with growth failure and rickets. Other features include altered mental status, abdominal pain, peripheral neuropathy, and/or respiratory failure requiring mechanical ventilation.

Farber's disease is caused due to a deficiency of ceramidase and manifests as hoarseness, dermatitis, skeletal deformation, mental retardation. It is fatal in early life.

questions.text: A woman delivers a baby at the primary health center. While examining the baby, you notice a foot deformity as shown in the image below. Screening for other defects and early cost-free intervention for this condition is covered under which of the following schemes?
questions.solution:
The condition seen in the given image is clubfoot (congenital talipes equinovarus or CTEV). Screening of this birth defect and early intervention are covered under the Rashtriya Bal Swasthya Karyakram scheme.

Rashtriya Bal Swasthya Karyakram (RBSK) is an important initiative aiming at early identification and early intervention for children from birth to 18 years to cover 4 ‘D’s which are:

  • Defects at birth
  • Deficiencies
  • Diseases
  • Development delays, including disability.

The first level of screening is done by medical officers, staff nurses, and ANMs, at all the places where deliveries are conducted. After 48 hours, up to 6 weeks, the screening of newborns will be done by ASHA at home as a part of the Home Based New-born Care (HBNC) package.

The target groups are divided into three groups based on age:

  • Newborn to 6 weeks
  • 6 weeks to 6 years
  • 6 years to 18 years.

They screen all the babies born at public health facilities and at home, preschool children in rural areas and urban slums, and children up to 12th grade enrolled in government schools.

Defects screened during birth :

  • Neural tube defect 
  • Down's Syndrome 
  • Cleft Lip & Palate / Cleft palate alone
  • Talipes (club foot)
  • Developmental dysplasia of the hip
  • Congenital cataract
  • Congenital deafness
  • Congenital heart diseases
  • Retinopathy of Prematurity

Other options :

Option B: Navjat Shishu Suraksha Karyakram: NSSK is a program aimed to train health personnel in basic newborn care and resuscitation, has been launched to address care at birth issues i.e. prevention of hypothermia, prevention of infection, early initiation of breastfeeding, and basic newborn resuscitation.

Option C: Janani Sishu Suraksha Karyakaram: It is an initiative to provide completely free and cashless services to pregnant women including normal deliveries and cesarean operations and sick newborns (up to 30 days after birth) in Government health institutions in both rural & urban areas.

Option D: Pradhan Mantri Surakshit Matritva Abhiyan: This program aims to provide assured, comprehensive, and quality antenatal care, free of cost, to all pregnant women on the 9th of every month.

questions.text: A 22-year-old college student reports feelings of low energy, lack of motivation, hopelessness, and feeling useless. She mentions that she has felt this way since her teenage years. There is no history suggestive of suicidal attempts, ideation, or any manic episodes. A diagnosis of dysthymia was made. Which is the most commonly used method of psychotherapy in this case?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario is consistent with the diagnosis of dysthymia, and the most commonly used therapy for treatment is insight-oriented therapy. Dysthymia refers to a persistent depressive mood lasting for more than 2 years (1 year in children and adolescents) but are not severe enough to be diagnosed as major depression.

DSM V Criteria for diagnosis of dysthymia: Depressed mood for most of the day as indicated by either subjective account or observation by others, for at least 2 years. In children and adolescents - at least 1 year.

Presence of two (or more) of the following while being depressed.

  • Poor appetite or overeating
  • Insomnia or hypersomnia
  • Low energy or fatigue
  • Low self-esteem
  • Poor concentration and/or difficulty making decisions
  • Feelings of hopelessness

As per DSM- 5, onset can be early -before 21 years of age or late -after 21 years of age.

The most effective treatment involves a combination of psychotherapy and pharmacotherapy. They include:

  • Insight-Oriented Psychotherapy (Psychoanalytic psychotherapy): It is the most common method and is considered the treatment of choice.  This therapeutic approach attempts at relating the depressive symptoms to unresolved conflicts from the past. The patient's relationships and current lifestyle are examined, and insight is gained.
  • Cognitive therapy: Patients are taught new ways of thinking and behaving, to replace negative and depressive attitudes about themselves, the world, and the future.
  • Behavioral therapy: Patients are made to focus on specific goals to increase activity, pleasant experiences, and relaxation. Altering per­sonal behavior is believed to be effective in changing depressed thoughts and feelings.
  • Interpersonal therapy: The patient's current interpersonal experi­ences and methods of coping with stress are examined to reduce depressive symptoms and to improve self-esteem. 
  • Family and group therapy: Helps both the patient and their family deal with the symptoms of the disorder. Group therapy may help withdrawn patients learn new ways to overcome their interper­sonal issues in social settings
  • Pharmacotherapy: Selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors (SSRIs) like venlafaxine and bupropion are effective.

Hospitalization is usually not indicated in dysthymia. However, severe symptoms, marked social or professional incapacitation, the need for exten­sive diagnostic procedures, and suicidal ideation are all indica­tions for hospitalization.

questions.text: A 40-year-old patient is under general anesthesia. Which of the following circuits is least effective for the prevention of rebreathing during spontaneous ventilation?
questions.solution:
Among the given options, the Bain circuit (modification of Mapleson D circuit) is the least effective for spontaneous ventilation. 

The relative efficiency of different Mapleson systems with respect to prevention of rebreathing during spontaneous ventilation:

Mapleson A > Mapleson D, F, E > Mapleson C, B. 

Mnemonic: A > DFE > CB : A Dog Can Bite (Usually a spontaneous event)

Mapleson A circuit is also known as Magill's circuit. It has an adjustable pressure limiting valve located near the facemask, and fresh gas flow enters the opposite end of the circuit near the reservoir bag. A corrugated tubing connects the reservoir bag near the machine end to the adjustable pressure limiting valve at the patient end of the system. It is the best circuit for spontaneous respiration as no rebreathing occurs with adequate flows.

 

Lack's circuit is a coaxial modification of the Mapleson A circuit. The only difference is that the expired gas is carried by an efferent tube placed coaxially and vented through the valve placed near the machine end.

 

Bain's circuit is a modification of the Mapleson D circuit, which is less effective than Mapleson A circuits for spontaneous respiration. Mapleson D is the most effective for controlled ventilation. During controlled ventilation, the relative efficiency of Mapleson systems are:

Mapleson DFE > Mapleson BC > Mapleson A

Mnemonic: DFE > BC > A : Dead Babies can't assist 

Related Pearl: Mapleson Classification

Mapleson circuit   Other name  Fresh gas flow rate
Spontaneous ventilation  Controlled ventilation
A Magills 1 minute ventilation (MV) i.e. 80 ml/kg/min Very high and difficult to predict
B - 2-3× (MV) 2-2.5 × (MV)
C Water’s to and fro 2-3 × (MV) 2-2.5 × (MV)
D Bain circuit 2-3 × (MV) 1-2 × (MV)
E Ayre’s t-piece 2-3 × (MV) 3 × (MV)
F Jackson rees modification 2-3 × (MV) 2 × (MV)

 

Note:

The efficiency of Mapleson circuits in spontaneous ventilation is  A > DFE > CB (A Dog Can Bite - Usually a spontaneous event)

The efficiency of Mapleson circuits in controlled ventilation is DFE > BC > A (Dead Babies can't assist - controlled)

questions.text:
A 3-year-old child was referred to the Ophthalmology department for evaluation of upper eyelid ptosis. Previous photographs suggest that it has been present from birth. The external eye measurements are given below. Which among the following surgeries is used to manage this case?
  Right eye Left eye
Palpebral fissure 4mm 4mm
Levator function Normal Poor
questions.solution:
Frontalis sling suspension is done for congenital ptosis with poor levator function.

Ptosis refers to the drooping of the upper eyelid such that it covers more than 2 mm of the superior cornea. It may be congenital or acquired.

Congenital Ptosis may be classified as:

  • Simple - isolated abnormality
  • Complicated -associated with ocular motor anomalies, blepharophimosis syndrome, and Marcus Gunn ptosis.

The presence of congenital ptosis should be confirmed by photographs taken during childhood. It is usually bilateral and is due to defective development of the muscle.

Measurements to assess ptosis:

  • Margin-reflex distance: The distance between the upper lid margin and the corneal reflection of a torch held by the examiner on which the patient fixates. It is normally 4–5 mm.
  • Palpebral fissure height: The distance between the upper and lower lid margins. It is measured in the pupillary plane. Normally it is 7–10 mm in males and 8–12 mm in females. Ptosis can be graded as
    • mild (up to 2 mm)
    • moderate (2-3 mm)
    • severe (4 mm or more)
  • Levator function (upper lid excursion): It is measured by placing the thumb firmly against the patient’s brow with the gaze fixed downwards. The patient is then asked to look up as much as possible and the amount of excursion is measured with a ruler. It is graded as:
    • Good:12–14 mm
    • Fair: 5–11 mm
    • Poor: 4 mm or less

When the levator function is poor (3 mm or less), the eyelid is suspended from the frontalis muscle using sutures, a fascia lata sling, or a silicone band. Infection of the suture bed is a complication of this surgery and the suture should be monitored.

Surgical treatment of various types of ptosis:

In patients with  good to moderate levator action:

Surgery Amount of ptosis that can be treated Indications
Fasanella Servat < 2 mm Horner Syndrome
Levator Resection – Anterior approach Any Larger resection in ptosis
Levator resection – Conjunctival approach Any Moderate resection in ptosis
Levator resection with aponeurotic reinsertion Any Acquired ptosis

In patients with poor levator action:

Surgery     Amount of ptosis that can be treated Indications
Frontalis suspension – Fascia lata > 2 mm Congenital ptosis, especially Marcus Gunn Ptosis

questions.text: A 26-year-old woman presents to the clinic with 6 weeks of amenorrhea. Her urine pregnancy test is positive. On bimanual examination, the apposition of vaginal and abdominal fingers is possible below the body of the uterus. What is this sign called?
questions.solution:
This sign described above is called Hegar's sign.

During bimanual examination, two fingers are placed in the anterior fornix and two fingers feel are on the abdomen, behind the uterus. Around 6-10 weeks of gestation, the growing fetus leads to enlargement of the upper part of the uterus, while the lower part is empty and soft. The cervix is firm in consistency. Because of this, apposition of the abdominal and vaginal fingers, below the body of the uterus, is possible on bimanual examination. This is called the Hegar's sign.

Other options:

Option A- A bluish tint of the ectocervix due to increased vascularity- Chadwick's sign

Option C- Cervical edema and softening- Goodell sign

Option D- Increased pulsations felt through the lateral fornices - Osiander's sign

Related Pearl: Uterine Signs in Pregnancy

questions.text: A 25-year-old man presented with a slowly progressive swelling with pain in the middle of his right leg. Microscopic examination of a biopsied specimen showed epithelial cells in a fibrous stroma as shown in the image below. He is diagnosed with an adamantinoma. What do you expect to see on an X-ray of the lesion?

choices.text: Sharply demarcated radiolucent lesions in tibial diaphysis
Soft tissue mass with extensive calcification
Homogenously lytic lesion with lack of calcification
Ground glass appearance of bone with multiloculated lesions

questions.solution:
An X-ray of an adamantinoma shows multiple sharply demarcated radiolucent lesions in the tibial diaphysis and honeycomb/soap bubble appearance.

Adamantinoma is a rare tumor of the diaphysis and presents commonly with pain and mild swelling in the front of the leg. It usually presents in the 2nd or 3rd decade and arises from the epithelial cells. 

On examination, there is thickening and tenderness along the subcutaneous border of the tibia.

Histology shows islands of epithelial-like cells (can have an acinar arrangement) in a densely populated stroma of spindle cells.

Adamantinoma is a low-grade tumor that metastasizes late – and usually only after repeated and inadequate attempts at removal. Complete excision of the tumor is the treatment of choice. 

The following image shows an X-ray and gross specimen of an adamantinoma.

Other options:

Option B: An x-ray showing a soft tissue mass, sometimes with extensive calcification is seen in synovial sarcoma. It usually develops near synovial joints in adolescents and young adults. The patient usually complains of rapid enlargement of a lump around one of the larger joints – the hip, the knee, or the shoulder. Pain is a common feature and many lesions are present for years before they are diagnosed. Biopsy reveals a fleshy lesion composed of proliferative synovial cells and fibroblastic tissue.

Option C: An X-ray showing a soap-bubble/ loculated appearance due to the tumor being homogeneously lytic and trabeculae of the remnants of bone traversing it and absence of calcification is seen in an osteoclastoma. It is seen commonly in the age group of 20-40 years. The bones affected commonly are those around the knee. The tumor is located at the epiphysis. Common presenting complaints are swelling and vague pain. Sometimes, the patient, unaware of the lesion, presents for the first time with a pathological fracture through the lesion. Microscopically, the tumor consists of undifferentiated spindle cells profusely interspersed with multi-nucleated giant cells.

The below image shows an x-ray of the knee joint depicting the soap bubble appearance:

 

Option D: An X-ray showing translucent to ground-glass appearance in the affected bone with the lesion being multiloculated, expanding the cortex of the bone is seen in osteofibrous dysplasia. It is a disorder in which the normal bone is replaced by fibrous tissue. It may affect only one bone (monostotic), or many bones (polyostotic). Often in the polyostotic variety, the bones of a single limb are affected and pain, deformity, and pathological fracture are the common presenting symptoms. The histological picture is that of loose, cellular fibrous tissue with widespread patches of woven bone and scattered giant cells.

questions.text: A young man presents with a history of head injury. On examination, his pulse rate is 52/minute, blood pressure is 168/100 mm Hg, and respiratory rate is 10/min. Which among the following options is responsible for the raised blood pressure in this patient?
questions.solution:
The reflex responsible for elevated BP in a patient with a head injury is the Cushing reflex. The Cushing reflex is a triad of:

  • Reflex bradycardia (via arterial baroreceptors)
  • Hypertension (with widened pulse pressure)
  • Irregular respiration (bradypnea).

When intracranial pressure is increased, the blood supply to rostral ventrolateral neurons is compromised. This leads to local hypoxia and hypercapnia which in turn increase the discharge of the central chemoreceptors located on the ventrolateral medullary surface. This activation causes a rise in blood pressure which then restores the blood flow to the medulla. However, the arterial baroreceptors sense this increase in the systemic blood pressure and cause a reflex decrease in the heart rate. 

Other options-

Option A: J Reflex is due to the stimulation of the J-receptors (C receptors/juxta-pulmonary capillary receptors) which causes a reflex increase in respiratory rate and dyspnea. 

Option B: Bainbridge reflex is the reflex responsible for tachycardia during right atrial distension. The stretch receptors of the atria that elicit the Bainbridge reflex transmit their afferent signals through the vagus nerves to the medulla of the brain. Then efferent signals are transmitted back through vagal and sympathetic nerves to increase heart rate and strength of heart contraction.

Option C: Bezold-Jarisch reflex is due to the activation of chemosensitive vagal C fibers in the cardiopulmonary region (e.g. Juxta capillary region of alveoli, ventricles, atria, great veins, and pulmonary artery). This is characterized by profound brady­cardia, hypotension, and a brief period of apnea followed by rapid shallow breathing.

Related Pearl: Intracranial Hypertension

Definition

Intracranial hypertension is pressure within the cranium above normal. Normal range of ICP is 5-15mm Hg. Levels above 20-25mm Hg are usually treated. 

Causes: Intracranial haemorrhage, brain tumors, head injury, meningitis, brain abscess, etc. 

Symptoms of raised ICT

  • Cushing’s triad – hypertension, bradycardia and respiratory depression
  • Headache, visual blurring due to papilloedema and abducent nerve palsy 
  • Focal symptoms may arise due to the local effects in patients with mass lesions or due to herniation.
  • Seizures
  • Stroke

Investigations

  • CT brain or MRI brain with gadolinium to rule out ICSOL 
  • Lumbar puncture is contraindicated in the presence of raised ICT due to the risk of coning.
  • Papilledema (as an indicator of ICT) should be ruled out before lumbar puncture.

Treatment

  • Dexamethasone
  • Ventriculotomy to remove CSF or ventriculoperitoneal shunt
  • Decompressive craniectomy
  • Surgical resection of ICSOL – by craniotomy or stereotactic radiosurgery
  • Whole brain radiation for multiple metastases causing raised ICT

questions.text: A 45-year-old obese patient presents with autophony. He says he can even hear the sounds of his breath and this gets exaggerated when he performs pranayama. He recently undertook a rapid weight loss program and lost 45 kgs over three months. The image below shows the procedure performed and the instrument used, for the management of his condition. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario with a clinical history suggestive of rapid weight loss, patient hearing his voice (autophony) and the symptom getting exaggerated while attempting to breathe after closing opposite nostril (as performed during Yoga) is seen in patulous eustachian tube/ overtly/ abnormally patent eustachian tube. 

The treatment of this condition includes eustachian tube catheterization as shown in the image. Image A and B are steps involved in the procedure while image C shows the eustachian tube catheter. It is actually a curved, metal cannula, measuring about 5 inches in length. Its tip is curved gently downwards. It is used to catheterize the Eustachian tube and is also used to remove foreign bodies in the nose. 

Patulous eustachian tube: In this condition, the eustachian tube is abnormally patent. The patient’s primary complaints are hearing his voice & breathing sounds, which is known as autophony. 

The most common cause is idiopathic. It is commonly seen after rapid weight loss. The Ostmann fat pads are located inferomedial to the eustachian tubes and are important in the normal closure of the Eustachian tube, preventing transmission of nasopharyngeal pressure to the middle ear. Acute and significant loss of weight leading to loss of adipocytes in the Ostmann fat pad can lead to tubal dysfunction.

Treatment includes weight gain, administration of potassium iodide solution. Long-standing cases or specific treatment could include cauterization of tubes or insertion of the grommet.

Other options:

Option A: Tubal blockage: Can be acute or chronic. It can be reversed physiologically or by yawning or Valsalva maneuver. Symptoms include those associated with the development of negative pressure in the middle ear cavity, with sequelae being a collection of fluid and infection to hemorrhage. Other symptoms include otalgia, hearing loss, popping sensations, rarely vertigo. It is treated by relieving the obstruction, treating the cause like infection or inflammation, and preventing or averting infection by antibiotic supplementation.

Options B and D: Retracted eustachian tube/atelectasis of the tubes could be due to obstruction at any path between the eustachian tube and attic. Retraction pockets could be formed which if left untreated can lead to sclerotic changes or atelectasis. Management includes surgical clearing of pockets and the establishment of ventilation. Antibiotic supplementation is a must to avoid middle ear infections.

questions.text: A 16-year-old girl is brought to the dermatologist after developing a rash on the exposed portion of her arm, face, and back after jogging as seen in the image below. She is presently being treated for acne vulgaris. Which of the following medications used for the treatment of acne vulgaris, influenced the severity of the patient's sunburn?
questions.solution:
The medication used for the treatment of acne vulgaris that influenced the severity of the patient's sunburn is doxycycline.

The age of the patient, physical examination and past history of acne vulgaris along with the image and presenting symptoms suggest a sunburn while being on treatment for inflammatory acne vulgaris. Doxycycline, an oral tetracycline antibiotic used in the treatment of acne vulgaris has been known to cause photosensitivity.

Photosensitivity refers to the appearance (or, exacerbation) of various skin symptoms on exposure to sunlight. Skin conditions caused by exposure to sunlight are called photodermatoses.

Acne vulgaris is commonly seen in teenagers and young adults. The clinical lesions are non‐inflammatory open and closed comedones and/or papules, pustules, and nodules of varying degrees of inflammation and depth. The face, back, and/or chest are the most frequently affected sites. Post‐inflammatory macules, pigment changes, and scarring commonly occur.

Other options:

Option A: Spironolactone is a potassium-sparing diuretic that is used in the treatment of acne but does not cause photosensitivity. Dermatologic side effects are not seen.

Options C and D: Dapsone and topical azelaic acid are used in the treatment of inflammatory acne. The most common side effects are local erythema, dryness, and pruritus.

Note: Other medications which cause photosensitivity include minocycline, benzoyl peroxide, and retinoids.

questions.text:
A young woman came with a 2-day history of dysuria and increased urinary frequency. She is sexually active and does not use condoms regularly. Examination reveals suprapubic tenderness. On antibiotic sensitivity testing, Novobiocin resistance is seen. Which of the following is the most likely cause of her symptoms?

Labs:

TLC: 10,200/mm3

Urine analysis:

pH: 6.8

Protein: trace

WBC: 80/hpf

Nitrites: negative

Bacteria: positive
questions.solution:
The patient has signs and symptoms of UTI (cystitis)- dysuria, increased frequency with suprapubic tenderness. Her urine analysis shows infection with nitrite negative bacteria. The antibiotic sensitivity shows novobiocin resistance, pointing towards Staphylococcus saprophyticus. It is a common cause of UTI in sexually active young females.

Staphylococcus saprophyticus is a coagulase-negative, novobiocin-resistant, non-hemolytic bacteria that is a normal flora of the vaginal tract. These bacteria do not convert nitrate to nitrite.

Other options:

Option A: Proteus mirabilis can also cause UTI. It produces a urease enzyme that alkalizes the urine. It is not the most common cause of UTI in sexually active females.

Option B: E.coli- This would have been the case if the test would have shown nitrite positive. It is the most common cause of UTI in all age groups.

Option C: N. gonorrhoeae causes urethritis, cervicitis, and PID, but not cystitis.

questions.text: A dead body is brought in for postmortem immediately after the death. You notice that the temperature of the body remains raised for about the first two hours after death. This can occur due to all of the following except:
questions.solution:
The condition in which the temperature of the body remains raised for about first two hours after death is termed postmortem caloricity. It is not seen in cases of drowning.

Strychnine poisoning, septicaemia and sunstroke lead to an increase in body temperature for the first 2 hours following death.

The condition occurs:

  • When the regulation of body temperature has been severely disturbed before death as in sunstroke, pontine haemorrhage.
  • Increased heat production in muscles due to convulsions as in tetanus and strychnine poisoning.
  • When there has been increased bacterial activity as in septicaemia, cholera.

Other options:

Cooling of the body after death is termed as algor mortis. In case of drowning, cooling of the body in water will be faster because, water is a better conductor of heat. Cooling in still water is about twice as fast as in air, and in flowing water, it is about three times as fast.

questions.text: Which of the following is a vascular phenomenon of infective endocarditis?
questions.solution:
Janeway lesions are due to a vascular phenomenon in infective endocarditis.

Janeway lesions are non-tender, erythematous, or hemorrhagic macular or nodular lesions, which are present on the palms or soles. They are vascular lesions caused due to deposition of septic emboli in the dermis. 

Other vascular manifestations of  include:

  • Septic pulmonary infarcts
  • Mycotic aneurysm
  • Splinter hemorrhages
  • Conjunctival hemorrhages

 

Immunological presentations of infective endocarditis include:

  • Glomerulonephritis
  • Roth spots
  • Positive rheumatoid factor
  • Osler's node - these are small, tender, red papules that are present on the distal finger and toe pads.

Related Pearl: Modified Duke's criteria for diagnosis of infective endocarditis

Diagnosis of Infective endocarditis is by Duke's Criteria, which requires either:

  1. Pathologic criteria
  2. Clinical criteria

If clinical criteria are used, definitive endocarditis is defined by the presence of 2 major or 1 major + 3 minor or 5 minor criteria.

The presence of single pathological criteria is definitive of infective endocarditis.

Note: The diagnosis of endocarditis is rejected if an alternative diagnosis is established either when:

  • Symptoms resolve and do not recur with <4 days of antibiotic therapy OR
  • If surgery or autopsy yields no pathologic or macroscopic evidence of endocarditis in <4 days of antimicrobial therapy.

questions.text: You have been invited to a child's birthday party. On reaching his home, you notice him ride a tricycle to the stairs and then get off, climb the stairs with alternate feet to reach his room. He has built a tower of 9 blocks in his room and is able to copy a circle using the glitter pens you gifted him. What is the likely age that these milestones correspond to?
questions.solution:
These milestones correspond to an age of 3 years.

The milestones attained by a child at age 3 are:

  • Gross motor development: Can ride a tricycle and walk up the stairs with alternate feet
  • Fine motor development: Can build a tower of 9 blocks and can copy a circle
  • Social and adaptive: Shares toys, begins to count, can identify 1-2 colors 
  • Language: Continually asks questions, knows full name

questions.text: A young patient who suffered a large wound due to a road traffic accident was referred to you after initial wound management. As a plastic surgeon, you decide to cover the wound with the following type of graft. Which of the following is not a feature of the graft used by the plastic surgeon?

choices.text: It is also known as Thiersch graft
Only dressing is enough at donor site
This graft has the best cosmetic appearance

questions.solution:
The given image shows the procedure of obtaining a split-thickness skin graft using a handheld Humby knife. The best cosmetic appearance is generally seen with full-thickness skin grafts. 

The most preferable donor site is buttock in cosmetically sensitive individuals and children. The most commonly used donor site is the thigh.

  • The graft is taken from the donor site with a handheld Humby knife or dermatome knife.
  • Grafts are perforated to allow exudates to escape and improve ‘take’. It can further be meshed to allow expansion.
  • Grafts will take up only on the beds which are vascularized, hence preparation of wound bed is an essential step.
  • Skin grafts are completely dependent on nutrition on the tissue over which they are placed and can heal well over muscle, perichondrium, and periosteum. They do not take well over bone or cartilage or on tissue that has been irradiated or infected or is hypovascular.
  • A clean healthy wound bed with a meshed graft tied in place to stop movement will encourage take.
  • The presence of group A beta-hemolytic streptococci is a contraindication in grafting as it can destroy split grafts completely and also convert donors to full-thickness defects.
  • The donor area is dressed appropriately and the dressing is opened after 10 days and not earlier. 

The given image shows Humby's knife. The average thickness of the graft obtained from a Humbys knife is 0.3 mm.

 

Split thickness skin graft (Thiersch graft ): Partial-thickness skin grafts consisting of the epidermis and a portion of the dermis are called split-thickness skin grafts.

Full-thickness skin grafts (Wolfe graft) include the epidermis and entire dermis, with portions of the sweat glands, sebaceous glands, and hair follicles. 

Advantages of split skin graft over full-thickness skin graft:

  • Large grafts can be harvested.
  • In the case of thinner split-thickness grafts, the donor site heals more rapidly and can be reused in severe cases such as burns.
  • Uptake is good. Meshing can be done i.e. small splits are made in graft and any exudates collected can come out through this and this improves graft take up. 
  • Meshing also allows the graft to expand.

Advantages of full-thickness skin graft over split skin graft:

  • It has a lesser degree of post graft contraction
  • Best cosmetic appearance as they include the highest number of skin appendage elements.

Related Pearl: Skin Grafting : Phases of Graft Uptake

Skin graft uptake occurs in three phases:

  1. Imbibition (Plasmatic circulation): During the first 48 hours, the graft is nourished with plasma exudate from the host bed capillaries.
  2. Inosculation: Cut vessels from the host bed line up with the cut ends of the vessels of the graft to form anastomoses.
  3. Neovascularization: Blood vessels grow from the recipient bed into the graft.

Sensations return to the graft over time, with reinnervation beginning at approximately 4 to 5 weeks and being completed by 12 to 24 months. Pain returns first, followed by light touch and temperature returning later.

Note: Some books give that the 3 phases are imbibition, revascularisation (inosculation+neovascularisation) and organisation (fibrin layer holds the graft in place and this is replaced with fibroblasts by day 7).
